This report was prepared by Yang Dan, team leader, Central Operations and Services Office.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the 2004 Country Programming Mission to the People’s Republic of China (PRC), 
the PRC Government confirmed its request for technical assistance (TA)1 from the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) to support development of the PRC consulting industry as a follow-up 
to the previous two ADB-supported TA projects.2 A TA fact-finding mission was fielded from 30 
August to 3 September 2004. During the mission, the Government requested that the TA focus 
on  formulating  a  regulation  to  enforce  application  of  the  Guidelines  on  selection  and 
engagement of consultants for Government-financed projects that was developed under TA 
3138 PRC (Guidelines). This report is based on the mission’s findings in the field, and the 
understanding  reached  with  the  Government  on  the  objectives  and  outputs,  scope,  cost 
estimates  and  financing  plan,  implementation  arrangements,  and  terms  of  reference  for 
consultants for the TA. Appendix 1 gives the logical framework. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Along  with  the  PRC’s  high  economic  growth,  its  consulting  industry  has  grown 
substantially in the past 25 years, to about 3,000 multidisciplinary consulting organizations. The 
rapid buildup of the industry was evidenced by a 13.8 factor increase of the total annual 
consulting revenue in 5 years, from $160 million in 1996 to $3.7 billion in 2001. The industry’s 
growth was partly due to the Government’s requirement that all decisions in investment projects 
be based on feasibility studies. National consultants have served clients of various sectors in 
both domestic and overseas markets and have helped prepare and implement development 
projects  financed  by  international  aid  organizations,  including  the  World  Bank  and  ADB. 
National consultants have also provided advisory support to the Government in economic policy 
formulation and restructuring of government administration.  
 
3.  Despite fast growth, the PRC consulting industry is still relatively immature. ADB has 
been requested to provide support for development of the industry since 1995. Major issues 
facing the industry were identified through provision of two ADB TAs. In 1995 the findings of TA 
2273 PRC highlighted that the industry was lacking (i) a framework to administer and coordinate 
the consulting industry at the national level; (ii) accessibility to information; (iii) competition and 
equal opportunity among government-owned and private consulting firms; (iv) a certification or 
accreditation system; and (v) public awareness regarding the capacity of consulting services. 
The TA recommended options to develop a regulatory framework to resolve these issues; 
progress has since been made.    
 
4.  In 1999, ADB provided TA 3138 PRC to help the Government strengthen its agencies’ 
capacities  to regulate, register, select, and engage consultants to ensure that procedures are 
consistent  with  a  market-oriented  economy  and  are  aligned  with  internationally  accepted 
standards  in  terms  of  efficiency,  transparency,  and  competitiveness.  The  TA  prepared  (i) 
Guidelines for the Selection and Engagement of Consultants for Government Financed Projects 
in PRC and (ii) a training manual to facilitate dissemination of the Guidelines. The Guidelines 
define  principles  and  procedures  for  selecting  and  engaging  consultants  for  government-
financed  projects.  The  Guidelines  are  also  to  standardize  consulting  services  terminology 
nationwide, and to create an environment of open competition and transparency in consultant 
selection and engagement. Under the TA, the Guidelines were pilot-tested in two government

2  
projects, with positive feedback from the project executing agencies and consultants. Although 
the Guidelines were an important step in the right direction in applying competitive market-
oriented principles, they do not include legal requirements for enforcement. A regulation based 
on the Guidelines, consistent with PRC procurement legislation, is needed to enforce their 
national application. Therefore, TA 3138 PRC recommended two follow-up actions: (i) that the 
Guidelines be converted to the Regulation for the Selection and Engagement of Consultants 
(Regulation)  and  (ii)  that  the  Guidelines  be  disseminated  through  training  workshops  to 
concerned government agencies and consulting organizations. 
 
5.  Although some issues identified under TA 2273 PRC have not yet been resolved, 
subsequent economic development in PRC has accelerated growth of its consulting industry. 
After the Government’s 1997 decision to undertake a nationwide ownership reform to vitalize 
state-owned-enterprises, the Ninth National Congress, held in 1998, passed resolutions to 
restructure government institutions. Even though reform has been slower than expected, mainly 
because of the nonavailability of a supporting and comprehensive social security system, the 
reforms have created a better environment for open and fair competition, as many previously 
government-owned consulting organizations are becoming self-supported.    
 
6.  In July 2004, the State Council approved Government Decree No. 20 on Reform of the 
PRC Investment System. The objective is to decentralize the government administration system 
for investment projects and simplify government approval procedures. The new investment 
policy requires a comprehensive regulatory framework for open and fair competition in the 
investment market to diversify investment resources and improve investment efficiency. With 
the new policy now in place, consulting services will play a key role in pre-investment feasibility 
studies  as  well  as  in  preparation,  implementation,  supervision,  and  post-evaluation  of 
investment projects. Consequently, the need is urgent to formulate regulations for selection and 
hiring of consultants for government-financed projects that create an environment of efficiency, 
competitiveness, and transparency.   
 
7.  The  Government  is  aware  of  the  need  for  a  regulatory  framework  to  support  a 
decentralized and market-oriented consulting industry. Because ADB earlier provided TA to the 
Government to develop national procurement regulations,3 the Government requested this TA  
to formulate a regulation to govern the rapidly growing consulting industry. Considering the 
more narrow sectoral focus of the Ministry of Science and Technology (MST), the Executing 
Agency (EA) for TA 3138 PRC, the Government identified the  National Development and 
Reform Commission (NDRC) which has broader-based mandate compared to MST, to be EA 
for the TA. 
    
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
8.  The objective of the advisory TA is to help the Government formulate the Regulation for 
Selection and Engagement of Consultants and disseminate it to enforce application of the 
Guidelines nationwide. Intensive training will be provided to government executing agencies and 
consulting organizations and firms after Government approval of the Regulation. Use of the 
Guidelines by project executing agencies will ensure that consultants with required expertise are

3
selected  at  appropriate  market  cost  for  government-financed  projects.  Formulation  of  the 
Regulation is in line with the Government’s overachieving goal to achieve good governance, 
improve economic efficiency, and combat corruption to develop a modern and effective market-
oriented economy.     
 
 9,  The TA will (i) update the Guidelines prepared under TA 3138 PRC; (ii) draft a regulation 
based  on  the  updated  Guidelines;  (iii)  develop  training  manuals  for  the  Regulation  and 
Guidelines as attachments to the Regulation; (iv) conduct dissemination and training workshops 
for concerned government agencies and consulting organizations and firms; and (v) develop a 
framework for a monitoring mechanism for the Government to enforce implementation of the 
Regulation and the Guidelines.     
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The TA will undertake the following key activities: (i) review the experiences and lessons 
learned in the pilot application of the Guidelines prepared under TA 3138 PRC; (ii) review 
generally applicable procedures now used for Government-financed projects; (iii) update the 
Guidelines as necessary, based on the review of (i) and (ii); (iv) draft the Regulation based on 
the updated Guidelines; (v) conduct review and consultation workshops to obtain inputs and 
comments on the draft Regulation from concerned line ministries and representatives of the 
consulting industry; (vi) finalize the draft Regulation for NDRC’s approval; (vii) develop training 
manuals and conducting intensive training programs, including training workshops and training 
of trainers programs on the Regulation and Guidelines for concerned government agencies and 
consulting organizations and firms; (viii) launch a national awareness campaign by holding new 
release  conferences  and  posting  the  Regulation  and  Guidelines  on  relevant  Government 
authorized  websites,  newspapers  and  magazines;  and  (viii)  develop  the  framework  for  a 
monitoring  mechanism  for  NDRC  and  concerned  line  ministries  to  establish  an  effective 
monitoring system to implement the Regulation and Guidelines.             
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
11.  The TA cost is estimated at $390,000 equivalent, of which $103,000 is foreign exchange 
cost and $287,000 equivalent is local currency cost. The Government has requested ADB to 
finance  $300,000  equivalent,  covering  the  entire  foreign  exchange  cost  and  $197,000 
equivalent of the local currency cost. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA 
funding program. The Government will finance the balance of the local currency cost, equivalent 
to $90,000, through remuneration and per diem of counterpart staff, office accommodation and 
communication facilities, training venue and facilities, interpreting services, and administrative 
support. Appendix 2 gives detailed cost estimates and the proposed financing plan.   
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
12.  NDRC will be the EA for the TA. Within NDRC, the Investment Department will supervise 
the consultants in drafting the Regulation, and coordinate with concerned line ministries to 
achieve endorsement of the Regulation and organize training workshops for dissemination of 
the Regulation and Guidelines. NDRC is anticipated to approve and issue the Regulation as a 
Government decree during the third quarter of 2005. An advisory committee will be established, 
comprising senior representatives from MOF, NDRC, MST, the Ministry of Commerce, and the 
Ministry of Construction to guide TA implementation. The advisory committee will work closely 
with NDRC to establish a monitoring and mechanism system to enforce project executing 
agencies to apply the Regulation and Guidelines. A senior official, at the director general level in

4  
the NDRC investment department, will be project director for TA execution. The China National 
Association  of  Engineering  Consultants  (CNAEC),  affiliated  to  NDRC  as  PRC’s  largest 
consulting association, will help NDRC’s investment department in TA implementation. CNAEC 
will also help NDRC organize training workshops and post the Regulation and Guidelines on 
relevant  government-authorized  web  sites,  and  in  newspapers  and  magazines,  including 
CNAEC’s web site and monthly magazine.   
 
13.  The TA should begin in March 2005, and will be implemented in two phases over 18 
months. During the first phase, consultants will review and update the Guidelines prepared 
under TA 3138 PRC. Based on the revised Guidelines, consultants will draft the regulation, to 
be reviewed in consultation workshops. Comments will be incorporated in the draft Regulation.  
The Regulation will be finalized in the format of a legal government document, and will be 
endorsed jointly by concerned line ministries before NDRC’s approval. After NDRC’s approval 
and issuance of the Regulation, phase two of the TA will focus on dissemination of the 
Regulation and Guidelines through various training programs, including training workshops and 
training of trainers programs. The trainees will be from central and provincial government 
agencies across the country, and from large consulting firms at the national and provincial 
levels.  
 
14.  The TA will require 3 person-months of international and 15 person-months of domestic 
consultants. Appendix 3 outlines the terms of reference for consultants. All consultants will be 
recruited on individual bases in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for engagement of domestic consultants.  
 
15.  The domestic consulting services specialist-team leader will, in collaboration with other 
consultants,  consolidate  and  submit  reports  required  by  ADB.  An  inception  report  will  be 
submitted to ADB and NDRC within 2 weeks after TA fieldwork begins, which will include a 
detailed work plan including the methodology for drafting the Regulation, its time frame for 
finalization  and  approval,  and  the  methodology  for  dissemination  of  the  Regulation  and 
Guidelines. This will be reviewed and approved by ADB and NDRC at the first tripartite meeting 
in consultation with the advisory committee. An interim report that includes the draft Regulation 
and a training plan will be submitted within 3 months after submission of the inception report. 
The Advisory Committee and consulting industry representatives will review and comment on 
the draft regulation at consultation workshops. The training consultant will design training 
programs and prepare training manuals for the Regulation and Guidelines. Two sets of training 
manuals will be prepared: one for government agencies, and the other for consulting firms. 
Upon NDRC’s approval and issuance of the Regulation, the training consultant will conduct 
training workshops with assistance from CNAEC and other consultants. The training consultant 
will submit a brief training evaluation report after each training workshop. Based on the training, 
consultants will help NDRC and concerned line ministries develop a framework monitoring 
mechanism to implement the Regulation and Guidelines. The draft final report, to be submitted 
within 2 months before TA completion, will include (i) an overall evaluation of dissemination and 
training for the Regulation and Guidelines, (ii) a framework of the monitoring mechanism, and 
(iii) recommendations for follow-up actions to further strengthen the regulatory framework for the 
PRC consulting industry. Consultants will submit the final report to ADB and NDRC within 1 
month after the final tripartite meeting.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by  the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $300,000 on a grant basis to

5
the  Government  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  for  Formulation  of  the  Regulation  for 
Selection  and  Engagement  of  Consultants  for  Government-Financed  Projects,  and  hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will require the services of one international and four 
domestic consultants. All consultants will be recruited on individual bases in accordance with 
the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (Guidelines) and 
other  arrangements  acceptable  to  ADB  for  engagement  of  domestic  consultants.  An 
international consulting services specialist will provide 3 person-months of inputs; the expert 
should have extensive international experience in administration in the consulting industry, and 
good  knowledge  of  international  consulting  practices.  The  expert  should  be  familiar  with 
guidelines and procedures for recruitment of consultants used by international aid organizations 
and  other  ADB  member  countries.  The  expert  should  also  have  experience  and  skills  in 
developing training materials and designing training workshops in the context of the People’s 
Republic of China (PRC).    
 
2.  The inputs of four individual domestic consultants are estimated at 15 person-months 
consisting of (i) 7 person-months to be provided by a consulting services specialist-team leader 
with good knowledge of PRC consulting industry administration and consulting services and 
proven capacity to coordinate with concerned government agencies; (ii) 3 person-months by a 
legal adviser familiar with PRC legislation relating to government procurement and consulting 
services; (iii) 4 person-months by a training specialist with intensive experience in developing 
training materials, designing  and conducting training programs, who is also familiar with PRC 
consulting practices; and (iv) 1 person-month by a website development specialist.  
 
A.  Specific Responsibilities and Tasks for Consultants  
 
1.  International Consulting Services Specialist (3 person-months) 
 
3.  The specialist will 
(i)      update  the  Guidelines  for  Selection  and  Engagement  of  Consultants  for 
Government-Financed Projects (Guidelines) prepared under TA 3138 PRC to 
ensure  that  they  meet      best-practice  international  consulting  service 
procedures;   
(ii)  guide  the  National  Development  and  Reform  Commission  (NDRC)  in 
collection  and  assessment  of  materials  relating  to  other  government 
guidelines and procedures of market economies as references in drafting the 
Regulation for Selection and Engagement of Consultants for Government-
Financed Projects (Regulation);     
(iii)  review the draft Regulation to ensure that it is consistent with the revised 
Guidelines; 
(iv)  undertake  quality  control  and  guide  the  preparation  of  the  final  English 
version of the Regulation;  
(v)  review  and  revise  the  English  edition  of  the  training  manual  for  the 
Guidelines, prepared under TA 3138 PRC, based on the draft Regulation; 
(vi)  develop  two  sets  of  training  manuals,  in  English,  for  trainees  from

4.  Domestic Training Specialist (4 person-months) 
 
6.  The specialist will 
(i)  review the revised Guidelines and training manual prepared under TA 3138 
PRC; 
(ii)  define content of the training manuals, based on the draft Regulation and 
revised Guidelines; 
(iii)  help  the  international  consulting  services  specialist  develop  two  sets  of 
training  manuals;  one  will  be  for  trainees  from  concerned  government 
agencies and the other, for consulting organizations; help develop a training 
manual for training of trainers program; 
(iv)  design  training  programs  and  methodologies  for  training  workshops  and 
training of trainers program, and prepare a training plan within the TA time 
frame; 
(v)  conduct  training  workshops  for  concerned  government  agencies  and 
consulting firms, with assistance of CNAEC and other consultants; and 
(vi)  design  training  evaluation  criteria  and  templates;  prepare  brief  training

training evaluation report that includes recommendations on the need for 
follow-up training for the Regulation and Guidelines to include in the draft final

5.  Website Development Specialist (1 person-month) 
 
7.  The specialist will 
(i)  coordinate the posting of the Regulation and Guidelines on the Government-
authorized procurement and bidding web sites; 
(ii)  help CNAEC post the Regulation and Guidelines, including posting a brief 
training manual and frequent questions and answers on its web site; 
(iii)  develop  training  manuals  on  a  CD-ROM  suitable  for  distribution  via  the 
internet; and  
(iv)  expand CNAEC’s web site to include information on consulting opportunities, 
consulting professional codes of ethics, and profiles of member consultants, 
plus other information that consultants and clients generally need.
